data.title: 16 Best Places to Visit in Israel (ATTRACTION GUIDE ‚Ä¢ 2024)
data.meta_description: The 16 best places to visit in Israel - highlights of the Holy Land! The MUST SEES AND DOS on a trip to Israel.
data.text:
Let‚Äôs be upfront: perhaps no country on earth divides public opinion quite like Israel does.

It‚Äôs not a big country, but there are a lot of beautiful things to see in Israel. It‚Äôs an old land, older than even the biblical texts would have us believe. There are also ancient sites around Israel that perhaps carry more weight than we can ever comprehend.

That‚Äôs what the last couple of months here have felt like; an attempt to comprehend the incomprehensible. There are a lot of beautiful places in Israel filled with majesty, and there is also a lot that hurts the heart. It‚Äôs impossible to travel Israel without being confronted by these and it‚Äôs taken me nearly two months of learning about the country and experiencing that spectrum to come to a conclusion‚Ä¶

That there is much beauty in Israel.

That‚Äôs why I‚Äôve written this guide to Israel‚Äôs top places to visit: my top places to visit. It covers a bit of everything from Israel‚Äôs religious places and historical sites, to its stunning natural landscapes, to its mind-bending otherworld. This list, I feel, gives Israel ‚Äì and Palestine ‚Äì a fair coverage.

I understand that discussing Israel is a political minefield and that you‚Äôre sticking your toes in with the sharks and I respect that. But I also respect honesty and integrity and I‚Äôm gonna do my best to keep my digits intact! So without further digression, let‚Äôs have a look at my choice of the best places to visit in Israel ‚Äì the must-see sights and sites of the Holy Land!

#1 ‚Äì Tel Aviv ‚Äì Expected top of the places to visit in Israel list.

Sexy architecture and art.

Believe it or not, it can be cheap.

Extremely secular.

Listen, I‚Äôm not in love with Tel Aviv. I did, however, find a 6 shekel falafel, a bouldering gym, stellar Airbnb‚Äôs to stay in and dope exercise parks‚Ä¶ oh, and the dumpster diving is on-point too! One way or another, ‚ÄòThe White City‚Äô has Israel‚Äôs main international airport and everybody visits Tel Aviv regardless; it‚Äôs the best place to go in Israel (or more appropriately, the only place) that offers this vibe.

Why it‚Äôs awesome: The vibe I‚Äôm referring to is that modern, ‚Äúliberal‚Äù, hipster-chic, ‚ÄúWhy everything gotta cost money!‚Äù feels. I kinda thought it felt like San Francisco but then a guy from San Fran said it felt more like a European millennial-bourgey city. I can‚Äôt comment there so I‚Äôm just gonna say it‚Äôs comparable to Melbourne except the people aren‚Äôt quite as friendly.

But people love all those places? Exactly! What Tel Aviv offers, it brings in spades.

What to do there: Tel Aviv is the best place to visit in Israel for nightlife ‚Äì no arguments there. Pubs, dive bars, speakeasies, live music, jam nights, clubs, techno, house, good genres of electronic music (psytrance), Hebrew poetry slams: it‚Äôs all there!

There‚Äôs sick street art, buskers, and espressos at every turn. The beaches are excellent (and the sunsets are even better) but you‚Äôll want to head north or south from the main hub to escape the crowds. Jaffa is the old town (which Tel Aviv has built around) and here things get more historical and Arabic in vibes.

Ultimately, there are some of Israel‚Äôs tourist attractions in Tel Aviv but I‚Äôd say that, for most backpackers, Tel Aviv is the tourist attraction. People come here to live the Tel Avivian life and I‚Äôd also say that it‚Äôs a must-visit place in Israel to gather the full-scope of the complexity of the country. Tel Aviv is also very safe (for the region).

#2 ‚Äì Neve Sha‚Äôanan ‚Äì A place of interest in Israel for seeking complexity.

A cheaper area in Tel Aviv.

Another side of the city.

An important place to visit in Israel.

Still very much a part of Tel Aviv, Neve Sha‚Äôanan is another world. Seen as the ‚Äòunderbelly of Tel Aviv‚Äô, it‚Äôs become the home for Israel‚Äôs many refugees, impoverished, and unwashed. Here you‚Äôll find many of Tel Aviv‚Äôs low-class brothels, streetwalkers, and homeless muttering to themselves as they trawl for scraps. It‚Äôs not a dangerous place in Israel, however; violent crime statistics are very low in the country.

Why it‚Äôs awesome: It may not be everyone‚Äôs vibe but I love it! Things are cheaper, the scope of cuisine is spectacular, and it‚Äôs a delicious peek below Tel Aviv‚Äôs mask of acceptance. Rough or not, this is multiculturalism in Israel at its finest and also it‚Äôs a fantastic opportunity to see the dichotomy of the country.

What to do there: Eating is a great start! Authentic Sudanese, Eritrean, Chinese, Indian, Filipino, and more ‚Äì a nice alternative to when the cheap falafel and hummus gets old (spoiler: it never does).

A walk around the neighbourhood on Friday night (the start of Shabbat) when the rest of the city begins to hibernate offers some of the most chaotic vibrancy. It really felt like stepping back into Asia.

I ended up uncovering the area because of my work reviewing Abraham Tours. It‚Äôs definitely a tour I recommend and you can book through them or, even better, contact Rikki (she was the guide) to book directly: +972-52-217-6188. Whatever you choose to do, get Rikki: the girl knows her stuff ‚Äì crazy insightful!

#3 ‚Äì Jerusalem ‚Äì A famous place in Israel of biblical proportions!

The City of (the Abrahamic) God.

It‚Äôs Jerusalem.

Spectacular architecture.

I don‚Äôt really like Jerusalem either ‚Äì sorry! It still stands as the most famous place in Israel to visit though ‚Äì no contest. If Neve Sha‚Äôanan is another world, Jerusalem is another planet. Taking the one-hour drive from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem is enough to get culture shock.

Why it‚Äôs awesome: Dude, it‚Äôs Jerusalem! The city has had so many kingdoms within it, battles fought for it, and people who have died because of it (steadfastly avoiding the obvious Jesus joke). I don‚Äôt usually link Wikipedia but this shit be bonkers! Whether you‚Äôre looking for biblical sites in Israel, holy places to visit, or just history‚Ä¶ well‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs Jerusalem! If your looking for the best hostels to stay in, Jerusalem has got a fair few of those too.

What to do there: It‚Äôs the (disputed) capital of Israel and a big city; the vibe may be different to Tel Aviv but it still has all the offerings. Nightlife, markets, secrets, hustle and bustle ‚Äì just with more funny hats! The Old City of Jerusalem is definitely one of Israel‚Äôs must-sees.

Outside of that, I‚Äôd recommend just strolling Jerusalem‚Äôs neighbourhoods and absorbing the feeling. Stepping from the new city to the old, the Jewish to the Muslim Quarter, or from a secular area to an Ultra-Orthodox neighbourhood all offer they‚Äôre own level of inundation of the senses. Just be wary that you don‚Äôt contract Jerusalem Syndrome ‚Äì Jerusalem is crazy and I haven‚Äôt met someone who disagrees yet.

I‚Äôm not gonna spend all post plugging Abraham Tours, but the ‚ÄòMeet the Ultra Orthodox Tour‚Äô in Jerusalem was another of their‚Äôs that I thoroughly enjoyed. It‚Äôs for sure worth the consideration if you got the spare shekels.

#4 ‚Äì The Dead Sea ‚Äì Time for a fun place to visit in Israel!

Quintessential photo-ops!

Become a mud monster.

The water tastes like a fish‚Äôs taint.

It‚Äôs a stone‚Äôs throw from Jerusalem (and Tel Aviv ‚Äì Israel is small) and it‚Äôs the Dead Sea. You know, the sea so salty you can‚Äôt sink in it! You can still drown if you‚Äôre a dumbhead though.

Why it‚Äôs awesome: C‚Äômon, it‚Äôs the Dead Sea; this was a childhood dream of mine since I was six! If you want to talk about unique places in Israel and must-see things, this is it (unless you‚Äôve been to Jordan ‚Äì shh).

What to do there: As my friend reminded my perpetually-moving mind when we were there: ‚ÄúJust lie back, close your eyes, and feel the water take your weight.‚Äù Unless you have any open cuts on your body. Then you‚Äôre in for a world of pain!

We went to Kalia Beach which, sadly, costs ($17). It‚Äôs pretty much a day at the beach for Israelis ‚Äì complete with the ‚Äòlowest bar in the world‚Äô ‚Äì except with a bonus total exfoliation and searing agony of the eyeballs (AVOID).

If you want to find a free place to camp and dirtbag by the Dead Sea, they definitely exist, particularly in the south. People sleep out, build huts, and do them; I just never caught the name of one or followed it up. That‚Äôs your adventure!

Ein Gedi is also near the Dead Sea and is another crazy beautiful place to visit in Israel for some nature goodness.

Want to save money on accommodation?

We got you. For reals.

#5 ‚Äì Nazareth ‚Äì A popular place in Israel to praise Jesus.

Quiet (except at Christmas ‚Äì ugh).

Warm vibes.

Cats.

Nazareth is definitely a religious place to visit in Israel for the lovers of Jesus but I‚Äôm skirting that because it‚Äôs got nothing to do with why I love it. I came here after roughly two weeks in Tel Aviv and suddenly it felt like I could breathe again. Suddenly, I was in a place where the streets were quieter and the people weren‚Äôt inexplicably rude for no reason. Nazareth is chill.

Why it‚Äôs awesome: Nazareth is known as the ‚ÄúArab Capital of Israel‚Äù and that changes the vibes rather significantly. The food also changes but only marginally.

The old city (as usual) is mega-pretty and it just so happens that my favourite hostel in Israel is there too.

What to do there: You‚Äôll find a lot of Israel‚Äôs religious sites here pertaining to that Jesus feller (‚ÄôJesus of Nazareth‚Äô ‚Äì makes sense); Nazareth is the starting point of the Jesus Trail too. It‚Äôs not just Christian jazz though ‚Äì there‚Äôs a large Muslim population as well which means gorgeous mosques and echoing prayers at sundown.

For the Messiah-chasers, it‚Äôs a top tourist destination in Israel. However, for those who aren‚Äôt seeking biblical places to visit, it‚Äôs just a chill refuge from the admittedly challenging nature of backpacking in Israel. The city is full of cats and friendly folk, there are mountains around Nazareth to wander up, and you can practice some Arabic!

Check out Abu Ashraf ‚Äì the knaffeh is supreme ‚Äì and Abu Salem too. The drinks are a tad expensive but the decor is intoxicating and people-watching old Arabic men shredding the shesh-besh (backgammon) board never gets old.

#6 ‚Äì Bethlehem ‚Äì Starting off the places to visit in Palestine list.

Jesus again.

A gentle introduction to Palestine.

Phenomenal street art.

Since we covered Nazareth, we‚Äôre visiting the West Bank with the next few entries and Bethlehem is a good start. It‚Äôs still very much a top religious tourist attraction in Israel. I‚Äôd also say it‚Äôs one of the best starting places to visit in in Israel and Palestine if you‚Äôre ready to start the journey down the rabbit hole.

Why it‚Äôs awesome: The birthplace of Jesus is a good start! Past that, there are a few more of Israel‚Äôs sacred ancient sites and then there‚Äôs the wall. The barrier wall between the West Bank and Israel (that also annexes Rachel‚Äôs Tomb).

The wall goes by many names depending on your stance on the on the conflict and it‚Äôs all thin-ice-politics but regardless, the wall is definitely a must-see thing in Israel both for the awesome art and what it represents.

What to do there: There‚Äôs a whole host of the must-see biblical sites in Israel. The aforementioned Rachel‚Äôs Tomb, The Church of the Nativity (built over Jesus‚Äôs alleged birthplace), The Milk Grotto (ew)‚Ä¶ That‚Äôs just a small selection too.

The occupation wall is something else. It‚Äôs covered in graffiti from the humorous to the downright sobering and even includes some work from Banksy ‚Äì it‚Äôs the real reason I recommend visiting Bethlehem. The art is spectacular, and the selfie-ops are tempting, but when you‚Äôre trailing the wall just try to remember what you‚Äôre actually looking at under the street art.

Read the stories posted on the wall and take a moment to feel the gravitas of Palestine.

#7 ‚Äì Other Biblical Sites in Israel ‚Äì Rounding off the holy places to visit in Israel.

Before we head deeper into the West Bank, let‚Äôs round off the religious places to visit in Israel. To be fair, most of these are more places to visit in Palestine.

It‚Äôs not my jam but neither is orange marmalade and my mum loves both orange marmalade and Jesus and she‚Äôs the best! Let‚Äôs take a look at the remaining must-see biblical sites in Israel for all the lovers of orange marmalade:

Jericho: Of the ‚Äòwe made your walls fall down and then genocided the entire city‚Äô fame. Historically speaking, that probably didn‚Äôt happen, but the ruins here are old and well predate any biblical events (except, arguably, Genesis 1:1). They‚Äôre not super impressive but good for the archaeology/history buffs.

The Mount of Temptation: Presumed to be Mount Quarantania, this was where Jesus was tempted during a 40-day fast by Satan rocking up with a few delicately-rolled doobs and some Chocolate Fudge Brownie Ben & Jerry‚Äôs ice-cream (biblical accuracy not guaranteed). Mount Quarantania is right above Jericho and the monastery constructed underneath is actually a super pretty place to visit in Israel.

Mount Tabor: Close to Nazareth and the supposed location of the Transfiguration of Jesus. It‚Äôs also just a cool looking mountain!

Jordan River: And the Baptismal Site of Jesus Christ. For the record, I had a dunk, but it doesn‚Äôt count as baptism if you do it to yourself.

#8 ‚Äì The West Bank ‚Äì Palestine ‚Äì All important places to visit in Israel.

The people are kind.

The coffee and cigarettes are cheaper!

Street food is back.

Ok, ready to do this? Let‚Äôs go deeper.

Although there are some of Israel‚Äôs popular places scattered around the West Bank (namely, the aforementioned biblical sites), travelling to the West Bank for Palestine itself is not high on the standard itinerary for Israel. Although some may worry that it‚Äôs a dangerous place in Israel, my experience was that it‚Äôs not.

If visiting the West Bank is not for you, then that‚Äôs your choice and totally ok. BUT, you can‚Äôt really say you explored the secrets of Israel unless you explored all of it. There are more than just Israelis living in Israel.

Why it‚Äôs awesome: Look, there is definitely beauty in Palestine of the ‚Äòappeal to tourists‚Äô variety but that‚Äôs not necessarily why travel there. I actually found it heartbreaking. For those that aren‚Äôt used to travelling in developing countries, I imagine these feelings may only be compounded.

This is why I say that both Tel Aviv and the Palestinian cities and villages are both must-see places in Israel. The act of travelling only 70 km changes everything.

What to do there: Meet the people. The Palestinian places are safe in Israel and most people are not hostile in the slightest with tourists (yes, even Americans). You can potentially expect some India-esque moments to get some shekels off you so keep your smart traveller hat on. They‚Äôre welcoming and warm and just really excited to talk, both about Palestine and the world at large that they‚Äôll never be permitted to see.

If you want to get out in the villages, then I that applaud that. Otherwise, for the city life, Nablus is a tad more chill than Ramallah but they‚Äôre both going to give you a good understanding‚Ä¶ plus the food is the best!

Also, the Palestinian kids really know how to throw down for a good night! Check Radio in Ramallah on Thursdays. That‚Äôll get you started, at least.

#9 ‚Äì Hebron ‚Äì An extremely important thing to see in Israel.

You gotta see it to believe it.

It‚Äôs a place you must see in Israel.

Conveniently, super cheap!

I counted this separately from the other places to visit in the West Bank because it deserves it‚Äôs own entry. I met a traveller in Israel who enjoys seeking out alternative and darker places. I forewarned him that Hebron is heavy. Three days later I got a message:

Dude, this is fucking heavy‚Ä¶

Why it‚Äôs awesome: Short of Gaza, this is the best place to visit in Israel to see the conflict at its most real. The city is divided into two sections one of which is H1 ‚Äì the Palestinian side of the city. H1 sits behind walls, barbed-wire, and assault rifles brandished by the Israeli military. Inside is living standards much, much closer to a city in India than Tel Aviv.

It‚Äôs not ‚Äúawesome‚Äù; It‚Äôs heavy and it hurts and, ultimately, I feel it‚Äôs a must-see place in Israel. The only way to make up your own mind is to go there and I‚Äôm grateful I did. Broke Backpacker Senior Editor, Freeborn Aiden, also rates at is as the MUST SEE place in Israel if you want to even begin to understand the complexities.

What to do there: The main tourist attraction in Hebron is the Tomb of the Patriarchs, the supposed burial site of Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and their respective wives. The tomb itself is split in half ‚Äì a synagogue and a mosque.

Outside of that, I‚Äôd say, again, walk around H1 and meet the people. It won‚Äôt take long before you‚Äôre sitting and drinking coffee with a local.

This is the last Abraham Tour I‚Äôm mentioning. I did the Hebron Dual Narrative Tour and, although rushed (Hebron deserves more exploration), it‚Äôs still an extremely insightful tour that aptly displays the dualistic nature of the situation. It‚Äôs a recommendation.

Lastly, for these Palestinian areas, I think it‚Äôs well worth finding accommodation with a local. That could mean a homestay, an Airbnb in a shared space, or even Couchsurfing is super possible! One way or another, I think you‚Äôll get way more from the experience doing that than from staying in a hotel.

#10 ‚Äì Mitzpe Ramon ‚Äì Back to the most beautiful places to visit in Israel!

Sunset majesty.

Hippies unite!

Ganja ‚Äì that is all.

Ok, that‚Äôs it. Don‚Äôt worry; the rest of the list is only the pretty shit! Topping that off is Mitzpe Ramon, one of the best places to travel to in Israel for sunsets and smoke!

Why it‚Äôs awesome: Mitzpe Ramon is a town located on a ridge overlooking Makhtesh Ramon (Ramon Crater). I‚Äôll talk about the sheer stunning awesomeness of the Negev Desert and south Israel in a moment but suffice to say the outlook from the ridge is stunning!

Mitzpe Ramon has also become an epicentre for all things hippy in Israel. There‚Äôs a lively little community built around music, art, and creative expression and, of course, find a hippy, find joints. To be fair, you‚Äôll find joints everywhere in Israel.

What to do there: Smoke joints‚Ä¶? Oh, other than that? Hiking, for sure!

Israel is actually super dope for hiking and Mitzpe Ramon is no different. You have a whole host of trails at your disposal and they‚Äôre all blisteringly gorgeous! Just remember to take water‚Ä¶ and a joint‚Ä¶ maybe two.

#11 ‚Äì Eilat and Southern Israel ‚Äì My personal top place to visit in Israel (minus Eilat).

That desert, man.

The Red Sea!

Cross to Sinai in Egypt.

Ok, so I‚Äôm mostly going to skip over Eilat. The Red Sea is there which is rad but, otherwise, it‚Äôs a resort town: it feels like Vegas and it‚Äôs yukky and I don‚Äôt like it. Diving in Eilat is also a thing. So why talk about Eilat? Because everything around it is spectacular!

Why it‚Äôs awesome: The Negev Desert, the Red Sea, Sinai (in Egypt)‚Ä¶ For me, southern Israel was the only part I found that was truly felt uniquely beautiful (including Mitzpe Ramon ‚Äì yum) and it‚Äôs the most beautiful place in Israel for me. The Negev Desert legit looks like Mars at times and the Red Sea is crazy pretty! Sunrise, sunset‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs all good!

What to do there: Consider Eilat just your base for the nature. You‚Äôll find parties there at night obviously, but it‚Äôs way too flashy for my taste.

You‚Äôve got some pretty dope hiking in the area though; Timna Park and the Red Canyon are both excellent or you can just disappear into the desert‚Ä¶ on weekends. The rest of the time it‚Äôs a firing zone for the military sooo maybe a no go.

It‚Äôs also the Red Sea which means all things aquatic: there‚Äôs diving in Eilat, snorkelling, paddleboarding, sailing‚Ä¶ Pretty much anything that doesn‚Äôt require waves!

You can also cross to the Sinai region in Egypt which is equally common for Israeli tourists. It‚Äôs super beautiful but it‚Äôs technically not a ‚Äòplace to visit in Israel‚Äô so read our Backpacking Egypt Travel Guide for more info.

#12 ‚Äì Kibbutzim or Moshavim ‚Äì Both historical places in Israel and an escape.

The sounds of birds and cows.

Fruit from the trees.

Cheap living.

There‚Äôs a whole interesting history here with kibbutzim and the founding of the state of Israel, communities built on socialist ideals, and also just how things change over time. Long story short though, they started as agricultural communities built around communal living and work. The system has changed and restructured a lot in recent years, however.

Moshavim are similar but different. Still all about the agriculture and community but just a bit less about the socialist ideals!

Why it‚Äôs awesome: Firstly, the vibe just chills out a whole helluva a lot more once you reach a kibbutz or moshav, especially outside the urban centre of Israel. They‚Äôre agricultural communities which means nature, fresh food and veg, sometimes hippies and smoke, and an escape from the chaos!

The shared-lifestyles of these communities is really cool to observe. Israel has it‚Äôs own twist on the whole ‚Äòlack of privacy‚Äô thing in Asia (yes, Israel is still Asia) and aspects of it I really enjoy.

What to do there: Farm work, mainly. Kibbutzim have a long-standing history of taking in travellers in exchange for work (the OG Workaway) and although the game has changed pretty substantially, you‚Äôll still find farms seeking volunteers.

Alternatively, just rock up and camp in the fields for a night. They‚Äôre always super pretty and no one will really care as long as you don‚Äôt step on any of their crops. Again, it‚Äôs that ‚Äòlack of privacy‚Äô thing.

Any suggestions for best places to go in Israel for the kibbutz/moshav life? I spent some time in Kfar Yehezkel and the family vibes are high; here‚Äôs their Workaway page and our review of Workaway with a sweet, sexy bonus deal inside. I also camped out at Ramot Menashe, Dafna is supposed to be dope, and Samar down near Eilat is full of alternative vibes.

#13 Haifa and Acre ‚Äì Maybe not the best but still cool places to visit in Israel.

Cities but more chill.

Beaches but more chill.

A bit more harmony.

I lumped these two of Israel‚Äôs famous places together because they‚Äôre so close to each other. It‚Äôs perfectly reasonable to stay at one and day trip to the other. It‚Äôs like half-an-hour on the train.

Two seaport cities of mixed ethnic and religious distribution, there‚Äôs relative harmony here. They‚Äôre cities but they‚Äôre more chill cities. I think it‚Äôs the mountains nearby; mountain folk are always good.

Why it‚Äôs awesome: You get the beach, you get less crowds than in the centre, and you get mountains too! It‚Äôs literally the best of everything.

Although nothing like Tel Aviv, Haifa has grown as hub for younger Israelis and you‚Äôll find some cool stuff happening in the city. Hadar neighbourhood is a good start. Acre has a long history of being in a pretty strategic location so you‚Äôll find some cool old-world goodness there.

What to do there: A good daytrip from Haifa is the Mount Carmel National Park or you‚Äôve also got the considerably impressive Bahai Gardens that overlook the city and port. (I didn‚Äôt even know that the Bahai were a thing until I got to Haifa ‚Äì super interesting!)

Acre stands as one of Israel‚Äôs more historical places to visit with landmarks that date back to middle-ages and that whole Crusades shebang. There‚Äôs the almost entirely Arabic old city which also means markets which ALSO means cheap coffee, tobacco, pita, and za‚Äôatar‚Ä¶ Breakfast is served!

If it strikes your fancy, there are lots of volunteering options in Haifa with Worldpackers, a reputable organisation where you can lend a helping hand in exchange for accomodation. Check out our Worldpackers review to see if an immersive work exchange in Haifa fits your bill.

#14 ‚Äì Golan Heights ‚Äì For views and other must-see sights in Israel.

Lotsa nature!

Different vibes again.

Yay, snow!

You want some nature? The Golan is full of it! Heading this far up north is much like heading all the way south: you‚Äôre well outside the urban areas of Israel now.

The Golan Heights is the region occupied by Israel during the Six-Day-War in 1967 and up this way you‚Äôll meet many Syrian-Druze people many of which still hold no Israeli citizenship. Some are by choice, some are because of political tensions, it doesn‚Äôt matter ‚Äì the whole situation is messy. The point is, it‚Äôs pretty!

What it‚Äôs awesome: The Golan is a super beautiful place in Israel and a destination worth travelling too. Mountains and bits of greenery or, hell, you‚Äôll even get snow at the right time in the right places! There are villages around for sure, and Israeli settlements too (not unpacking that dynamite-laced Pandora‚Äôs Box, thank you), but everything is much more spread out.

This one is for the nature.

What to do there: Odem is a good base. The Golan Heights Hostel is there which draws in a good vibe of traveller (you know the one I mean). For solo backpackers travelling in Israel especially, I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs second only to Me‚Äôever.

If you‚Äôre there in winter, and got the cash to flash, Mount Hermon is the best place to go in Israel for skiing! And also the only! And I use the word ‚Äòbest‚Äô very loosely because it‚Äôs Israel and not exactly famed for skiing.

Or, if you‚Äôre interested in the Syrian-Druze people and life, head to Madjal Shams below the majesty of Mount Hermon. Believe it or not, there‚Äôs a dope little arts scene!

#15 ‚Äì Sea of Galilee ‚Äì The top attraction of Israel‚Äôs Galilee region.

Last of Israel‚Äôs three big bodies of water.

This one is freshwater.

And full of fish.
